turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Violence against LGBT people.
turn.1: When was the crime of sodomy made illegal?
turn.2: This act was replaced in 1828, but sodomy remained punishable by death under the new act until 1861.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: In Nazi Germany, homosexuals were among the groups targeted by the Holocaust ("See Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust").
turn.7: Was there any other instances of violence?
turn.8: (In 1936, the homosexual Federico García Lorca was executed by right-wing rebels who became Franco's dictatorship in Spain, Hitler's ally.) Neo-Nazis generally oppose homosexuality to the extent of supporting a renewed persecution the way it took place in Nazi Germany.
turn.9: Why were they viewed as unmasculine?
turn.10: Being homosexual is equated with being unmasculine and the German word ″Schwul″ ('gay') is used by German Neonazis as a curse word.  , 72 countries criminalize consensual sexual acts between adults of the same sex.
turn.11: Is it ever OK to be gay?
turn.12: They are punishable by death in eight countries:  Countries where homosexual acts are criminalized but not punished by death, by region, include:  Africa Asia America Pacific Islands Afghanistan, where such acts remain punishable with fines and a prison sentence, dropped the death penalty after the fall of the Taliban in 2001, who had mandated it from 1996.
